awd_titl_txt: AGS-PRF: Sensitivity Analysis of Carbonaceous Aerosol Mixing State and Morphology on Spectral Optical Properties
awd_abstract_narration:
Small atmospheric particles, known as aerosols, can impact weather and climate through their interaction with clouds and radiation.  In this project, research will take place to determine how aerosol size, shape, and composition impacts the interaction of aerosols with radiation.  This project will focus on black carbon, which is emitted from various combustion sources such as forest fires and vehicle exhaust.  The main result of the project would be a quantitative estimation of the sensitivity of radiative properties to aerosol morphology and composition, which will help to improve climate model simulations.  The postdoctoral researcher also plans to conduct various education and outreach activities, such as teaching a college course, mentoring undergraduate students, and providing research opportunities to high school students.

The researcher plans to conduct a project to systematically understand and parameterize the sensitivity of the spectral optical properties of carbonaceous aerosols to variations in aerosol morphology, refractive index, and external mixing.  The approach will be computational in nature involving the use of state-of-the-art aerosol simulation techniques and non-spherical particle-electromagnetic radiation interaction codes.   Four main research questions are posed:  1) How do the physical properties of black carbon aerosol evolve as a function of organic carbon coating?  2)  How do the intensive optical properties and extensive optical properties differ for bare black carbon morphology and those with external mixing with organic carbon?  3)  What is the spectral response of bare and externally-mixed black carbon?  4)  What corrections are needed to spherical core-shell calculations, conventionally used in climate models, with regard to incorporating non-spherical black carbon particles with and without organic carbon mixing?

por.por_cntn:
Recent comments in the journal Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences called the lack of agreement on soot’s light absorption magnitude “one of the grand challenges in atmospheric climate science”. Soot has the ability to absorb sunlight and heat the atmosphere. Thus, climate scientists must incorporate soot in their models to better predict future warming trends. Soot is treated simplistically as solid spheres of pure, black carbon aerosol. In reality, soot morphology is complex, with a fibrous open structure.

Furthermore, these particles are mixed, or coated, with organic aerosols that are co-emitted with soot from wildfires. The complexity of the soot structure does have a significant influence on their optical properties. For example, black carbon absorbs more light when it is coated with non-absorbing organic materials, but the amount of absorption enhancement varies depending on how much coating is present. A major finding of my research is that the absorption enhancement due to the coating can be described by a simple power law expression. I first created simulated particles that looked just like those found in nature, with varying degrees of the organic coating, then, using precise computational calculations, I measured their light absorption. When I plotted the absorption against the amount of organic coating, the result was found to be a power law. Which means that as the amount of coating increases, the particle’s light absorption goes up proportionately by a power law with a one-third exponent. My findings also point to the fact that warming due to soot may be underestimated by climate models. Assuming spherical shape and not properly accounting for light absorption enhancement by coating could result in significantly lower warming estimates. Rahul Zaveri, a senior scientist at Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, called my findings a significant and timely advancement and said,

“I am particularly excited about the mathematical elegance and extreme computational efficiency of the new parameterization, which can be quite readily implemented in climate models once the companion parameterization for light scattering by coated black carbon particles is developed.”

My research focused on studying the effects of soot structure and coating on optical properties. My work in this area has been selected as an “Editors’ Suggestion” published online Nov. 2018 in the prestigious journal Physical Review Letters, and has been presented at the 10th International Aerosol Conference, 17th Electromagnetic and Light Scattering Conference, and AGU Fall Meeting in Washington, DC.
